Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Situation2: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Story:
I stared at my phone, my sister’s message lighting up the screen: “Don’t forget, dinner at 7. Mom’s making your favorite.” I could almost smell the food already, and I knew how much it meant to my family that I showed up, especially since we hadn’t all been together in weeks. But just as I was about to reply, another message popped up—this time from Mia. “Can we talk? I’m really upset about earlier. I thought we were spending Saturday together.” My stomach twisted. I could hear the hurt in her words, and I knew if I didn’t call her soon, things might get worse. 

I felt pulled in two directions. My family expected me to be present, to laugh and share stories at the dinner table. But Mia needed me to listen, to reassure her that she mattered most. I wanted to be the dependable brother and the caring boyfriend, but tonight, I couldn’t be both. My heart pounded as I weighed my choices, feeling the pressure of letting someone down no matter what I did.
